<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Good morning. </strong>Disney is not throwing away its shot in the room where it happens because this is the story of tonight and it wants to blow us all away in addition to leaving us helpless and satisfied, knowing that you’ll be back one last time to hear the story of tonight (reprise).</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Did we do that right? A recording of <em>Hamilton</em> is coming to Disney+ on July 3, more than a year ahead of schedule.</p>

</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Economy: </strong></span><span>Dr. Anthony Fauci, the country’s top infectious disease official, told a Senate committee yesterday that hasty reopenings that don’t follow health guidelines could </span><span><a href="https://apnews.com/e64f20bbacb7d48d15e1d76339220486?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">result in</a></span><span> “needless suffering and death.” </span>

The bill includes $875 billion for state and local governments, $175 billion for testing and healthcare, and $75 billion in housing assistance. It adds up to $3 trillion total.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Budget: </strong></span><span><img src="https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/face-with-open-mouth_1f62e.png" width="18" style="max-width:18px" alt="">. The U.S. budget deficit grew to a record </span><span><a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-economy-budget/us-reports-record-738-billion-budget-deficit-in-april-idUSKBN22O2SG?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">$738 billion</a></span><span> in April. </span>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
REAL ESTATE
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/12/twitter-announces-blanket-work-home-policy-signaling-shift?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Offices Clock Out
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Home office" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC85MzMvaG9tZV9vZmZpY2UuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday, Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey <a href="https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/alexkantrowitz/twitter-will-allow-employees-to-work-at-home-forever?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">wrote in an email</a> to employees that the company will allow almost everyone to work from home permanently. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Dorsey had said he planned to make Twitter’s workforce more “distributed” before the coronavirus pandemic, but then...those plans got pushed up. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture: </strong>Office closures have forced many companies to try remote working. Google said a majority of Googlers will WFH until 2021, and Facebook will allow all employees who are able to WFH to do so even after it reopens offices after the July 4 weekend. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">And it’s not just tech: The pandemic prompted members of the button-down brigade like Morgan Stanley and Barclays to add security measures that allow employees to WFH, to generally positive results. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>One report by NordVPN found that average workdays have </span><span><a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/03/30/coronavirus-lockdowns-are-making-the-working-day-longer-for-many.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">stretched</a></span><span> three hours</span><span><em> longer</em></span><span> since lockdowns began. Feel that. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">The real estate implications </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">This could signal a turning point for a commercial real estate trend that’s been gaining steam for over 100 years. Since the late 19th century, a company without an office has been no company at all. But as the economic outlook gets bleaker, anxious execs could eagerly ditch leases while employees work from their breakfast nooks. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Commercial real estate leases often last 10 years, and very few firms are currently in a position to make 10-year decisions. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Google owner Alphabet has stopped real estate deals for over 2 million sq. ft. of new office space since the pandemic began, </span><span><a href="https://marker.medium.com/the-office-is-dead-16be89f25d01?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">per Marker</a></span><span>. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">For companies that do return to offices, the digs will look different. Staff might work alternate days and be herded by sensors and markings to enforce social distancing—and architects say the long-abandoned cubicle’s comeback has arrived. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>real estate is slow to react to economic contractions, so we probably won’t see the peak of any office exodus until 2021 at least.</p>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
DEBT
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/12/fed-kicks-off-750b-corporate-bondbuying-program?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Boom Boom Powell
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Jerome Powell testifying before Congress" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC84MC9qZXJvbWVfcG93ZWxsLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>U.S. Federal Reserve</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In late March, Fed Chair Jerome Powell soothed markets with lullabies of unprecedented economic stimulus. Yesterday, the central bank made good on his promise to buy corporate debt for the first time in history by kicking off a $750 billion lending program. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">What the Fed is doing:</strong> Providing relief to capital markets by <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/12/business/dealbook/fed-bond-etf.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">buying exchange-traded funds</a> invested in corporate debt. The Fed will mostly buy investment-grade bonds, with some junk bonds as well.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Jerome’s got help </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The Fed drafted BlackRock, the world’s largest asset manager, to <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/big-money-managers-take-lead-role-in-managing-coronavirus-stimulus-11589130185?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">administer</a> the program. It isn’t the first time the central bank has asked private companies for a hand: During the financial crisis, money management firms helped the Fed “handle toxic assets.” </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">BlackRock will do what it normally does—investing clients’ money in line with their goals. It’s just that this time the Fed’s the client, the money’s in the upper nine figures, and the stakes couldn’t be higher.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture: </strong>Some economists are concerned BlackRock could unfairly boost its ETFs, but the Fed has established clear guidelines for BlackRock to avoid conflicts of interest, the WSJ reports.</p>

</a>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
FOOD DELIVERY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/12/uber-reportedly-interested-grubhub-acquisition?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Rub a Dub Dub, Thanks for the Grubhub
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="Bart Simpson GIF " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=506 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/l2JefalPnnlvzTmlW/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="Bart Simpson GIF " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/l2JefalPnnlvzTmlW/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Uber is <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/12/technology/uber-grubhub-deal.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">looking to acquire</a> food delivery service Grubhub, according to multiple reports. Grubhub shares shot up 29% as if it were a soggy burger excited to finally become someone’s dinner.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>Food delivery is a fierce business, so consolidation was <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/food-delivery-firms-put-mergers-ipos-on-the-menu-11582030802?mod=article_inline&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">on the menu</a> this year, global pandemic or not. The WSJ reported in February that industry players like Uber, DoorDash, and Postmates were already sketching out ways they might combine to not completely cannibalize one another. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">For Uber, this could be a seamless acquisition in more ways than one. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Its food delivery arm, Uber Eats, has been surging during the lockdowns, with Q1 bookings </span><span><a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/05/07/uber-uber-earnings-q1-2020.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">up over 50%</a></span><span> annually. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>However, the company’s core rides business was down about 80% in April, forcing it to implement harsh cost-cutting measures. Last week, Uber laid off 3,700 employees, or 14% of its total workforce. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But it’s not crawling into a shell. Besides its reported interest in Grubhub, Uber is leading a $170 million investment in e-scooter and bike company Lime.</p>

</a><span>  </span>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SPONSORED BY POLICYGENIUS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="#" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">

Look, Mom! We’re Officially Adults
</font></a>
</h1>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">This didn’t happen when we started making our own dentist appointments or even when we landed a job at the world’s most impressive electronic business newsletter. Policygenius simplifies the process of getting covered by handling all the hard, boring stuff (like scheduling and paperwork) at <strong style="color:#000">no extra cost</strong>.</p>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
CONSUMER
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/12/consumer-price-index-experiences-worst-drop-since-financial-crisis?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Prices Go Down Like a Punctured Moon Bounce
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">We knew something was up with consumer prices after we traded our neighbor 2 oz. of yeast for a Caribbean timeshare. But yesterday’s release from the Bureau of Labor Statistics paints a more detailed picture. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In April, the consumer price index (CPI) experienced its <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/05/12/core-consumer-prices-saw-the-largest-monthly-drop-ever-in-april.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">sharpest monthly decline</a> since the Great Recession. CPI is an indicator of prices for a “basket” of typical consumer goods and services, from food and medical care to transportation. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Core CPI, which removes volatile food and fuel costs from the picture, fell 0.4% in April, the biggest drop since record-keeping began in 1957. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Some outliers: Food at home (groceries) rose a record 2.6%. The biggest drops were transportation and apparel—4.7% apiece.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture: </strong>April was the second month in a row CPI declined. If the trend continues, some economists fear we’ll experience <a href="https://apnews.com/e5b0dfe25ff2cb4f53477ba8c0b445d7?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">deflation</a>, a prolonged period of widespread decreases in prices and wages. That could make an economic recovery even harder, since people may hold off on purchases assuming goods will only get cheaper from here.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-top: 12px;">

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ADVERTISING
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/12/tv-advertisers-dramatically-dial-back-q3-spending?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Advertisers Aren't Buying Advertisements
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Don Draper" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8zMDcvbWFkX21lbi5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>AMC</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">So they’re just companies now, we suppose. Heavyweights like PepsiCo, GM, and General Mills are <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/from-pepsico-to-gm-big-advertisers-set-to-cancel-commitments-to-tv-networks-11589298017?mod=business_lead_pos3&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">backing out</a> of Q3 ad agreements with TV networks, the WSJ reports. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Starting May 1, companies were allowed to cancel up to 50% of their Q3 ad commitments (they’re required to give networks ~60 days' notice). And cancel they reportedly are—the drawback could total $1–$1.5 billion, per some estimates.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The normal ad buy calendar: </strong>Around May-ish, networks throw fêtes that make the Met Gala look like a potluck. Wined and dined advertisers make agreements called “upfronts” with networks way ahead of TV seasons’ September starts. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>But this May isn’t exactly fête-friendly, so networks are pitching via livestream...which is a bit less glamorous than Radio City Music Hall. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>Companies are reluctant to spend on TV ads because they’re anticipating 1) reduced consumer spending and 2) minimal new programming. Thus far, Fox is the only major broadcaster that has released a fall schedule.</p>

<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>A few other popular subjects include Serena Williams, the 2016 Chicago Cubs, Leicester City’s remarkable Premier League championship in 2016, and the U.S. women’s national soccer team.</span></li>

April. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/th\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c!--[if !mso style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0\"\u003e\nREAL ESTATE\n\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/12/twitter-announces-blanket-work-home-policy-signaling-shift?email={{profile.email}}\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nOffices Clock Out\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Home office\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC85MzMvaG9tZV9vZmZpY2UuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eFrancis Scialabba\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYesterday, Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey \u003ca href=\"https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/alexkantrowitz/twitter-will-allow-employees-to-work-at-home-forever?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewrote in an email\u003c/a\u003e to employees that the company will allow almost everyone to work from home permanently. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eDorsey had said he planned to make Twitter’s workforce more “distributed” before the coronavirus pandemic, but then...those plans got pushed up. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture: \u003c/strong\u003eOffice closures have forced many companies to try remote working. Google said a majority of Googlers will WFH until 2021, and Facebook will allow all employees who are able to WFH to do so even after it reopens offices after the July 4 weekend. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAnd it’s not just tech: The pandemic prompted members of the button-down brigade like Morgan Stanley and Barclays to add security measures that allow employees to WFH, to generally positive results. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eOne report by NordVPN found that average workdays have \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/03/30/coronavirus-lockdowns-are-making-the-working-day-longer-for-many.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003estretched\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e three hours\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cem\u003e longer\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e since lockdowns began. Feel that. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThe real estate implications \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThis could signal a turning point for a commercial real estate trend that’s been gaining steam for over 100 years. Since the late 19th century, a company without an office has been no company at all. But as the economic outlook gets bleaker, anxious execs could eagerly ditch leases while employees work from their breakfast nooks. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eCommercial real estate leases often last 10 years, and very few firms are currently in a position to make 10-year decisions. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eGoogle owner Alphabet has stopped real estate deals for over 2 million sq. ft. of new office space since the pandemic began, \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://marker.medium.com/the-office-is-dead-16be89f25d01?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eper Marker\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFor companies that do return to offices, the digs will look different. Staff might work alternate days and be herded by sensors and markings to enforce social distancing—and architects say the long-abandoned cubicle’s comeback has arrived. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003ereal estate is slow to react to economic contractions, so we probably won’t see the peak of any office exodus until 2021 at least.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eU.S. Federal Reserve\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn late March, Fed Chair Jerome Powell soothed markets with lullabies of unprecedented economic stimulus. Yesterday, the central bank made good on his promise to buy corporate debt for the first time in history by kicking off a $750 billion lending program. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhat the Fed is doing:\u003c/strong\u003e Providing relief to capital markets by \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/12/business/dealbook/fed-bond-etf.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ebuying exchange-traded funds\u003c/a\u003e invested in corporate debt. The Fed will mostly buy investment-grade bonds, with some junk bonds as well.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eJerome’s got help \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe Fed drafted BlackRock, the world’s largest asset manager, to \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/big-money-managers-take-lead-role-in-managing-coronavirus-stimulus-11589130185?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eadminister\u003c/a\u003e the program. It isn’t the first time the central bank has asked private companies for a hand: During the financial crisis, money management firms helped the Fed “handle toxic assets.” \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBlackRock will do what it normally does—investing clients’ money in line with their goals. It’s just that this time the Fed’s the client, the money’s in the upper nine figures, and the stakes couldn’t be higher.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture: \u003c/strong\u003eSome economists are concerned BlackRock could unfairly boost its ETFs, but the Fed has established clear guidelines for BlackRock to avoid conflicts of interest, the WSJ reports.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eUber is \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/12/technology/uber-grubhub-deal.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003elooking to acquire\u003c/a\u003e food delivery service Grubhub, according to multiple reports. Grubhub shares shot up 29% as if it were a soggy burger excited to finally become someone’s dinner.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eFood delivery is a fierce business, so consolidation was \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/food-delivery-firms-put-mergers-ipos-on-the-menu-11582030802?mod=article_inline\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eon the menu\u003c/a\u003e this year, global pandemic or not. The WSJ reported in February that industry players like Uber, DoorDash, and Postmates were already sketching out ways they might combine to not completely cannibalize one another. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFor Uber, this could be a seamless acquisition in more ways than one. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eIts food delivery arm, Uber Eats, has been surging during the lockdowns, with Q1 bookings \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/05/07/uber-uber-earnings-q1-2020.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eup over 50%\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e annually. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eHowever, the company’s core rides business was down about 80% in April, forcing it to implement harsh cost-cutting measures. Last week, Uber laid off 3,700 employees, or 14% of its total workforce. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut it’s not crawling into a shell. style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px\"\u003e\n\u003ca style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nPrices Go Down Like a Punctured Moon Bounce\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWe knew something was up with consumer prices after we traded our neighbor 2 oz. of yeast for a Caribbean timeshare. But yesterday’s release from the Bureau of Labor Statistics paints a more detailed picture. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn April, the consumer price index (CPI) experienced its \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/05/12/core-consumer-prices-saw-the-largest-monthly-drop-ever-in-april.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esharpest monthly decline\u003c/a\u003e since the Great Recession. CPI is an indicator of prices for a “basket” of typical consumer goods and services, from food and medical care to transportation. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eCore CPI, which removes volatile food and fuel costs from the picture, fell 0.4% in April, the biggest drop since record-keeping began in 1957. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eSome outliers: Food at home (groceries) rose a record 2.6%. The biggest drops were transportation and apparel—4.7% apiece.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture: \u003c/strong\u003eApril was the second month in a row CPI declined. If the trend continues, some economists fear we’ll experience \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/e5b0dfe25ff2cb4f53477ba8c0b445d7?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edeflation\u003c/a\u003e, a prolonged period of widespread decreases in prices and wages. That could make an economic recovery even harder, since people may hold off on purchases assuming goods will only get cheaper from here.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/12/tv-advertisers-dramatically-dial-back-q3-spending?email={{profile.email}}\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nAdvertisers Aren't Buying Advertisements\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Don Draper\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8zMDcvbWFkX21lbi5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eAMC\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSo they’re just companies now, we suppose. Heavyweights like PepsiCo, GM, and General Mills are \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/from-pepsico-to-gm-big-advertisers-set-to-cancel-commitments-to-tv-networks-11589298017?mod=business_lead_pos3\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ebacking out\u003c/a\u003e of Q3 ad agreements with TV networks, the WSJ reports. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eStarting May 1, companies were allowed to cancel up to 50% of their Q3 ad commitments (they’re required to give networks ~60 days' notice). And cancel they reportedly are—the drawback could total $1–$1.5 billion, per some estimates.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe normal ad buy calendar: \u003c/strong\u003eAround May-ish, networks throw fêtes that make the Met Gala look like a potluck. Wined and dined advertisers make agreements called “upfronts” with networks way ahead of TV seasons’ September starts. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eBut this May isn’t exactly fête-friendly, so networks are pitching via livestream...which is a bit less glamorous than Radio City Music Hall. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eCompanies are reluctant to spend on TV ads because they’re anticipating 1) reduced consumer spending and 2) minimal new programming. NASCAR races on ovals go counterclockwise (only turn left)\u003cbr\u003e5.
